journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Investigation of the injection process and combustion of a dimethyl ether engine with different nozzle flow areas

article-meta.aff: School of Energy and Power Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *School of Energy and Power Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an 710049, People’s Republic of China. email: shenghua@mail.xjtu.edu.cn

abstract.p: Dimethyl ether (DME) is a promising alternative fuel, which can be used as a substitute for fossil diesel fuels, with a smaller lower heating value. When used in diesel engines, the nozzle flow area (i.e. the number of nozzle holes × nozzle hole diameter) of the engine is normally increased to maintain the engine power. In this study, three kinds of nozzle (with nozzle flow areas of 5 × 0.30 mm, 5 × 0.35 mm, and 5 × 0.40 mm respectively) were prepared. With a two-cylinder diesel engine, the effects of the nozzle flow area on the DME injection process and combustion characteristics were investigated. The experimental results indicate that the DME acoustic velocity shows no variation with the change in the nozzle hole diameter and that the DME injection timing is not affected. However, as the nozzle hole diameter increased, the DME line pressure (and, in particular, the second peak of the line pressure on the nozzle side) is greatly decreased. Meanwhile, the fall of the needle valve lift is advanced, resulting in a decrease in the injection duration. Further, the engine ignition delay is slightly increased, the total combustion duration is slightly shortened, and the engine brake thermal efficiency is slightly elevated.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Fuel shortage and air pollution are two urgent worldwide issues related to the automobile industry. An alternative fuel is regarded as a feasible solution [1–5]. Dimethyl ether (DME) has been found to be a promising alternative fuel to diesel in engines owing to its suitable cetane number. The thermal efficiency of a DME engine is competitive with that of a diesel engine. Also, DME has a simple molecular structure (CH3OCH3) with a high oxygen content; therefore, a DME engine can achieve smokeless combustion and lower particulate matter (PM), hydrocarbon, carbon monoxide, and nitrate oxide (NOx) emissions [6–8]. Furthermore, a DME engine can have a higher ratio of exhaust gas recirculation to reduce NOx emissions further without the disadvantage of an increase in the PM or smoke emissions [9].

However, compared with diesel fuel, DME has a smaller lower heating value and a lower density. Therefore, when used in engines, more fuel should be delivered to maintain the engine power, i.e. the cyclic fuel quantity should be increased. As a result, the fuel injection parameters of the engine, including the plunger diameter and the plunger effective stroke of the fuel pump, as well as the nozzle flow area, should be rematched.

It has been proved that the fuel injection parameters have shown pronounced effects on the fuel injection process and the engine combustion characteristics [10–14]. However, there have been few reports in the literature concerning the DME injection process. Only a comparative study on the injection processes of a compression ignition (CI) engine when fuelled with diesel and DME has been carried out by Zhang et al. [15] and by Cipolat [16], respectively. These studies indicated that the DME delivery timing should be advanced in high-speed conditions owing to the lower DME acoustic velocity. The line pressure fluctuations are larger and the injection duration longer for DME than for diesel fuel. Also, the difference between the injection processes will finally affect the combustion of engine.

To understand further the fuel injection process of the DME engine, and to illustrate the relationship between the nozzle hole diameter dh and the DME injection process, in this study, three kinds of nozzle with different nozzle diameters dh were prepared, and the effects of dh on the DME injection process and engine combustion were investigated experimentally.

sec.title: 2 Experimental SET-UP
sec.p: The DME engine used in this study was retrofitted from a four-stroke water-cooled direct-injection diesel engine. The specifications of the engine are listed in Table 1. The plunger diameter of the original fuel pump was 0.85 mm. To generate equal rated power and maximum torque, a new fuel pump with a longer effective stroke plunger was adopted for the DME engine, and the plunger diameter was increased to 10.5 mm. Thus, the cyclic fuel quantity of DME engine was increased to about 2.1 times that of a diesel engine. Since DME has better evaporation and atomization characteristics than diesel fuel has [5, 6], the needle valve opening pressure of the DME engine was decreased. The number of nozzle holes and dh were increased simultaneously. In this study, three types of nozzle with dh = 0.31 mm, 0.35 mm, and 0.4 mm, respectively were used. Further, since the fuel temperature shows marked effects on the fuel injection process [14], the DME inlet temperature was stabilized to 30 °C, and this will be discussed further in this paper.

tr.td: Delivery timing (° CA before top dead centre)
Number of nozzle holes × nozzle hole diameter (mm)

sec.p: The engine operating conditions were selected on the basis of the ESC-13 mode test cycle of a diesel engine. In this study, speed B and speed C of the ESC-13 mode test cycle, i.e. 1870 r/min and 2340 r/min, were focused on. For each speed, engine loads (i.e. brake mean effective pressures (BMEPs)) of 0.167 MPa, 0.33 MPa, and 0.5 MPa were considered.

During the testing process, the engine was stabilized initially to certain operating conditions. The line pressure, the in-cylinder pressure, and the needle valve lift signals were then sampled. The line pressures on the pump and nozzle sides in the fuel injection pipe were found using Kistler 4067 style piezoresistive pressure sensors. The needle lift movement was measured with a needle valve lift sensor. A Kistler 6125A style of water-cooled piezoelectric pressure transducer was used to determine the cylinder pressure. The crankshaft position and the piston top dead centre signals were obtained with a Kistler 2013B optical rotary encoder. All these above signals were recorded using data acquisition apparatus (Yokogawa DL750). The fuel consumption quantity was acquired with two Siemens SITRANS FC300 mass flow meters which are installed in the DME-supplying and DME-spilling pipes, respectively.

sec.title: 3.1 DME injection process
sec.p: Figure 1 compares the line pressures and needle lift curves of the DME engine with different nozzles under various engine operating conditions. By analysing these curves for specific engine operating conditions, e.g. an engine speed n of 2340 r/min, a BMEP of 0.33 MPa, and a nozzle diameter dh of 0.35 mm, the DME fuel injection process can be summarized. The DME residual pressure in the injection pipe is about 5 MPa. At 22° crank angle (CA) before top dead centre, which is 3° CA after the fuel delivery timing, the line pressure ppump on the pump side starts to rise. The length of the fuel injection pipe is 550 mm. It takes DME a time equivalent to about 8° CA to be transferred to the nozzle side, resulting in a rise in the line pressure pnozzle on the nozzle side. Another 10° CA later, pnozzle reaches the needle valve opening pressure (i.e. 15 MPa), and the needle valve lifts. Meanwhile, the pressure rise becomes retarded owing to the outflow of DME. Thus, pnozzle continues to rise and then falls. The peak of pnozzle is even higher than that of ppump, and the second pressure peak on the nozzle side is formed owing to the reflection and build-up of the pressure wave. The nozzle lift closes at about 10° CA after top dead centre. Subsequently, pressure waves are continuously reflected many times and finally are reduced to the residual pressure.

caption.p: Comparison of the DME injection processes for different nozzles

sec.p: The increases in both the engine load and the engine speed have positive effects on the increase in the DME line pressure, as seen in Fig. 1. As the engine load increased, more power is supplied to the injection pump. This certainly results in an increase in the DME line pressure and, in particular, in the second pressure peak on the nozzle side. For the nozzle hole diameter of 0.31 mm, the second peak is just about 18 MPa at the lowest engine load (BMEP, 0.33 MPa), while it is about 28 MPa at the middle engine load (BMEP, 0.5 MPa). Thus, the increase in the engine load of 0.17 MPa results in a increase in the second pressure peak on the nozzle side of about 10 MPa. On the other hand, the increase in the engine speed shows more influence on the pressure peak value, but less influence on the curve shape.

With increasing dh, the flow resistance decreases, and the line pressure is decreased. As seen in Fig. 1, with an increase in dh from 0.31 mm to 0.4 mm, the decrement in the line pressure on the pump side is about 5 MPa, and the decrement in the second pressure peak on the nozzle side is higher, up to 12 MPa.

Further, for specific engine operating conditions, DME has the same elevation timing for the needle valve lift although different nozzles are used. This can contribute to the constant value of the acoustic velocity α for the DME fuel, which determines the fuel injection delay. For a specific engine, the fuel injection timing advances as α is increased. Thus, it is an important parameter to describe the fuel injection process. Based on experimental data, α can be calculated from the formula

where α is the acoustic velocity (m/s), Δt is the interval (s) of the increase in the line pressure from the fuel injection pump side to the nozzle side, and L is the length (m) between the two points where the line pressure is recorded. The α values for DME under different engine operating conditions are compared in Fig. 2. This figure shows that α for DME, which remains around 950 m/s in this study, does not vary with changes in the engine load, the speed, and the nozzle diameter dh. Also, a slight difference between the measurement results, which arises because of the experimental measurement error and the fuel temperature variation resulting from the fuel injection pump, is found. Furthermore, the largest relative error is just 1.6 per cent at the high engine load and thus can be ignored.

caption.p: Results of the α values for DME under different engine operating conditions

sec.p: The α value for DME can also be theoretically calculated from the elastic modulus and density value of the fuel using the formula [13]

where E and ρ are the elastic modulus (Pa) and density (kg/m3) of the fuel, respectively. Based on the DME thermal physical property data established by the Thermodynamics Research Group of Xi’an Jiaotong University [17], the α values for DME are calculated. As seen in Fig. 3, for a constant pressure of 20 MPa, with an increase in the fuel temperature from 10 °C to 60 °C, both E and ρ for DME fuel are decreased and, finally, the α value for DME is decreased from about 1100 m/s to only 900 m/s. It is indicated that α for DME is greatly affected by the fuel temperature. Therefore, in this study, the inlet fuel temperature was stabilized to 30 °C. It is proved by Fig. 2 that any influence of the fuel temperature on the α value for DME is avoided.

caption.p: Effects of the fuel temperature on the α, ρ, and E values for DME

sec.p: Also, owing to the increase in the line pressure on the nozzle side and, in particular, the increase in the second pressure peak, the fall of the needle valve lift is delayed. Thus, the increases in the engine load and the speed, and the decrease in the nozzle diameter dh all result in an increase in the fuel injection duration, as seen in Fig. 1.

sec.title: 3.2 DME combustion characteristics
sec.p: Based on the in-cylinder pressure, the engine heat release rate dQB/dφ and the combustion characteristics can be calculated [18]. In this study, the combustion timing is defined as the peak point of the second-order differential dp/dφ2 of the in-cylinder pressure. The end of the combustion is the timing when the accumulative heat release rate reaches 95 per cent. The interval between these above two points is the total combustion duration φtot. The ignition delay τig is defined as the interval between the initial rise in the needle valve and the combustion timing.

Figure 4 illustrates the in-cylinder pressure and heat release rate curves of DME engines with different nozzles. As seen in this figure, DME in-cylinder combustion is obviously affected by dh. At 1870 r/min, for both the middle engine load and the high engine load, the DME engine with a nozzle hole diameter of 0.31 mm has the highest in-cylinder pressure peak. With increases in dh to 0.35 and 0.4 mm, the peak is decreased and then increased. The combustion timing and the initial rise in the heat release rate curve are a little delayed. Also, the heat release rate peak is elevated and, meanwhile, the second heat release rate peak is decreased, indicating that more DME is burned during the premixed combustion phase. Furthermore, the DME engine with different nozzles has nearly the same accumulative heat release rate curve and the end of the combustion timing.

caption.p: Comparison of the in-cylinder pressure and the heat release rate curves of DME engines

sec.p: The τig and φtot values of DME engines with different nozzles are compared in Table 2. For specific engine operating conditions, all nozzles have the same initial rise timings of the needle valve lift, while the ignition timing is delayed slightly as dh increases. As a result, τig is increased. This can contribute to an increase in the fuel quantity which is injected at the initial few CAs of the fuel injection duration, which results in a decrease in the in-cylinder temperature.

Also, as dh increases, the ignition timing is delayed. However, for all nozzles, the combustion ends at nearly the same CA, as seen in Table 2. As a result, the engine φtot value is slightly shortened. For instance, at an engine speed of 1870 r/min, under the middle engine load, φtot for dh = 0.31 mm is 23.8° CA. With increases in dh to 0.35 mm and 0.4 mm, φtot is decreased to 23.2° CA and 22.9° CA, respectively, and the decrements are 0.6° CA and 0.9° CA, respectively. For the high engine load, the decrements are 0.1° CA and 0.6° CA for dh values of 0.35 mm and 0.4 mm, respectively.

caption.p: Comparison of the τig and φtot values for different nozzle diameters dh

tr.th: Value for the following operating conditions

sec.p: Also, the brake thermal efficiency ηet of the DME engine with different nozzle diameters dh are compared. It is defined as [19]

where P is the engine brake power (kW), mf is the fuel consumption rate (kg/s), and QHV is the fuel lower heating value (kJ/kg). A comparison of the ηet values for different nozzle diameters dh is given in Fig. 5. As dh increases, the engine φtot decreases slightly. As a result, the engine ηet increases slightly with increase in dh, as seen in Fig. 5.

caption.p: Comparison of the ηet values for different nozzles

sec.title: 4 Conclusion
sec.p: In this study, the fuel injection process and the combustion characteristics of DME engine with different nozzle diameters dh were investigated. The main conclusions are as follows.

list-item.p: The oil temperature shows a marked influence on the α value for DME. With an increase in the oil temperature from 10 °C to 60 °C, the α value for DME decreases from about 1100 m/s to only about 900 m/s. Comparatively, it is not affected by dh. For all nozzles, the same initial rise timings of the needle valve lift are observed.

The nozzle diameter dh shows pronounced effects on the line pressure on both the pump side and the nozzle side in the fuel injection pipe. As dh increases, the line pressure peaks for both the pump side and the nozzle side, and the second pressure peak on the nozzle side, are greatly decreased. The decrement in the second pressure peak on the nozzle side is the largest. As a result, the fall of the needle valve lift is advanced, and the fuel injection duration is shortened.

The combustion characteristics of the DME engine are also obviously affected by dh. With increasing dh, the engine τig value is slightly prolonged, while the engine φtot value is slightly shortened, which results in an increase in the engine ηet value.

tr.td: length between the two points where the line pressure is recorded (m)
line pressure on the nozzle side (MPa)
line pressure on the pump side (MPa)
lower heating value of the fuel (kJ/kg)
time interval during which the line pressure rises (s)
